descriptions.text: Instructions and functions related specifically to the Amiga. Implementation will be done as best as possible, yet, not all will be possible to emulate. Most of the instruction will compile, yet have simply have no effect in runtime.
Set hardware register for hardware Sprite collision detection. No effect in AOZ.
Return collision status after a Set Hardcol instruction. No effect in AOZ.
Reserved variable: pass values to and from 68000 address register. No effect in AOZ.
Reserved variable: pass values to and from 68000 address register. No effect in AOZ.
Re-start automatic copper generation. May be implemented in a future enhanced Amiga renderer.
Stop automatic copper generation. May be implemented in a future enhanced Amiga renderer.
Swap logical and physical copper lists. May be implemented in a future enhanced Amiga renderer.
Re-set copper list pointer. May be implemented in a future enhanced Amiga renderer.
Insert a WAIT instruction into copper list. May be implemented in a future enhanced Amiga renderer.
Write a long MOVE instruction to copper list. May be implemented in a future enhanced Amiga renderer.
Write a MOVE instruction to current copper list. May be implemented in a future enhanced Amiga renderer.
Give address of logical copper list. May be implemented in a future enhanced Amiga renderer.
Used to handle multiple applications in the AMOS IDE. Will not be implemented.
managed multi-tasking on the Amiga. May be implemented.
Bring AMOS IDE in the front of display. Will not be implemented.
Bring AMOS IDE in the back of display. Will not be implemented.
Detect if AMOS is running. Emulation returns TRUE

return.text: True

Engage double precision accuracy. Will not be implemented.
Use the Workbench system requester. Will not be implemented.
Use the AMOS Professional requester routine. Will not be implemented.
Used to cancel the requester. Will not be implemented.

descriptions.text: AOZ offers several instructions for managing connection interfaces.
A connection interface, called "Socket" allows the conversation between several remote computers. Like a chat or a multiplayer game.
More informations on Web Socket API here: https://www.w3.org/TR/websockets/
Open a connection to a remote server.

parameters.name: HOST$
parameters.text: Address of the server to be connected.

parameters.name: PORT
parameters.text: Port of the server to be connected.

parameters.name: ONOPEN$
parameters.text: Name of the AOZ procedure which should be called when the connection is successful.

parameters.name: ONMESSAGE$
parameters.text: Name of the AOZ procedure which should be called when your program received a new message from server.

parameters.name: ONCLOSE$
parameters.text: Name of the AOZ procedure which should be called when the connection is closed.

parameters.name: ONERROR$
parameters.text: Name of the AOZ procedure which should be called when your program received a error message from server.

exceptions.text: Address of the server is missing.
Port of the server is missing.
Name of the ONOPEN procedure is missing.
Name of the ONMESSAGE procedure is missing.
Name of the ONCLOSE procedure is missing.
Name of the ONERROR procedure is missing.

descriptions.text: Sending data to the remote server, which will be read by other connected users.

parameters.name: DATA$
parameters.text: Data, as a string, to send to the server.

descriptions.text: Close the connection opened with Socket Connect instruction.
Close the connection opened with Socket Connect instruction, with a code and a reason.

parameters.name: CODE
parameters.text: Code of the closure.

parameters.name: DATA$
parameters.text: Text of the reason of the closure.

descriptions.text: Instructions set to play sounds effects.
BOOM command plays a realistic explosive sound effect.
This does not delay the program at all, so it may be necessary to use WAIT between successive explosions,
or to create ricochet and echo effects.
Generate percussive sound effect.
The SHOOT command generates a simple sound effect in exactly the same way as Boom.
Generate pure tone.
Unlike the built-in explosive sound effects, Bell produces a simple pure tone.
Play a sound sample from the sample bank
The Sam Play command is used to play a digital sound sample through your audio system. Simply define the
number of the required sample held in the bank. There is no limit to the number of samples that can be stored, other
than available memory.

parameters.name: SAMPLE
parameters.text: Index of the sample into the bank to play

than available memory.

parameters.name: NAME$

descriptions.text: Instructions and functions to manage the timer and time in AOZ
Reserved variable. Return / Set the number of millisecond since the application was launched. Work in 1/50th of seconds in Amiga emulation
You can play music and sound effects inside your AOZ programs, using the old MOD and XM file formats.
The main advantage of this type of file is its small size. You can store music on several voices as well as sound effects. The AOZ instructions allow you to load and play your files.
AOZ uses the BassoonTracker Javascript library from Steffest, available under the MIT license.
Github: https://github.com/steffest/BassoonTracker
